columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to solve the time value of the option using the Black Scholes Model.

To start with, let us define  Black Scholes Model. 

**Black Scholes Model** is a mathematical equation that involves probabilities to compute the price of an option. 

The equation of the Black Scholes Model is illustrated as follows: 

$$\textbf{C}=\text{S}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d1})}-\text{X}\times\text{e}^{\text{-rt}}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d2)}}$$

Where: 

- C- Call Option
- S- Stock Price
- X - Exercise Price
- r - rate
- t - time
- N(d1) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d1
- N(d2) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d2

Whereas d1 is solved as follows: 

$$\textbf{d}_{1}=\frac{\left[\text{ln}\frac{\text{S}}{\text{X}}\right]+\left(\text{r}+\frac{σ^2}{2}\right)\times\text{t}}{\left(σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}\right)}$$

And d2's equation is illustrated below: 

$$\textbf{d}_{2}=\text{d}_{1}-σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}$$

Where: 

- σ - Standard deviation
- ln - natural logarithm

Here are the parameters to solve the problem : 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
| Stock price (S) |$59 | 
| Exercise price (X) |$55 | 
|Risk-free rate (r) | 2% | 
|Time (t) |6 months;6/12;0.50 | 
|Standard deviation(σ) | 54% per year| 
| e| 2.71828|

To start with, let us solve the natural logarithm of the quotient of the current stock price and the exercise price. 

We are going to use excel to solve the natural logarithm. The formula should look as follows: 


!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/01c1dfcb-4bfa-4a02-a81c-fe911ea8700b-1661686609901462.png)

Therefore ln(S/X) is 0.0702.

Next, let us solve d1 using the equation in Step 3: 


 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{1}&=\frac{0.0702+\left[0.02+\frac{0.54^2}{2}\right]\times0.50}{0.54\sqrt{0.50}}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{0.0702+\left[0.02+\frac{0.2916}{2}\right]\times0.50}{0.54\times0.7071}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{0.0702+\left[0.02+0.1458\right]\times0.50}{0.3818}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{0.0702+(0.1658\times0.50)}{0.3818}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{0.0702+0.0829}{0.3818}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{0.1531}{0.3818}\\[20pt]
&=0.401\space\text{or}\space0.40 \space\text{when rounded}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, d1 is 0.40.

Now, we solve the value of d2 using the equation in Step 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{2}&=0.40-0.54\times\sqrt{50}\\[15pt]
&=0.40-0.54\times0.7071\\[15pt]
&=0.40-0.38\\[15pt]
&=0.02
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of d2 is 0.02.

Now, here are the values of N(d1) and N(d2) using the cumulative normal distribution table: 


|Normal distribution | | 
|--|--| 
|Nd1 |0.5754 | 
|Nd2 |0.4364 |

Using the equation in Step 2, the value of the call option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{C}&=\$59\times0.6554-\$55\times2.71828^{-(0.02)(0.50)}\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$59\times0.6554-\$55\times2.71828^{-(0.01)}\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$59\times0.6554-\$55\times0.99\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$59\times0.6554-\$55\times0.5029\\[15pt]
&=\$38.67-\$27.66\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$11.01}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the value of the call option is $11.01.

Now, the equation of the put option is illustrated below: 

 

$$\textbf{P}=\text{X}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}+\text{C}-\text{S}$$

Where : 

- P - Put option
- X - Exercise price
- r - risk-free rate
- t - time
- C- Call option
- S - Stock price

## Requirement A

We are asked to solve the intrinsic value of the call and put option.

The intrinsic value of the call option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Intrinsic Value}&=\text{S}-\text{X}\\[15pt]
&=\$59-\$55\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$4}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

- S - Stock price
- X - Exercise price

The exercise price is deducted from the stock price to determine the intrinsic value of call option. 

Thus, the intrinsic value of the call option is $4.

The intrinsic value of the put option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Intrinsic Value}&=\text{X}-\text{S}\\[15pt]
&=\$55-\$59\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{-\$4,\space\text{or}\space0}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

- S - Stock price
- X - Exercise price

The stock price is deducted from the exercise price to determine the intrinsic value of the put option. 

Thus, the intrinsic value of the put option is 0.

## Requirement B

We are asked to solve the time value of the call and put the option. 

The equation of time value is illustrated below: 

$$\textbf{Time Value}=\text{Option price}-\text{Intrinsic Value}$$

The intrinsic value is deducted from the option price to determine the time value.

## Requirement C

We are asked to identify which has the higher time value. 

The time value of the call option is $7.01, while it is $6.46 for the put option. From the solved figures, the call option has the higher time value. However, this is not always the case because of volatility and fluctuations in the market.
